docs.lead_paragraph: Miss New Jersey, Ashley Harder, has resigned from the Miss U.S.A. pageant because she is pregnant, The Philadelphia Daily News reported yesterday. Ms. Harder, 20, of Marlton, who was crowned in October, told the newspaper that she was expecting a child by her companion in late summer. Pageant rules bar pregnant women. She has been replaced by Erin Abrahamson, 23, of Essex Fells, the newspaper said. The Miss U.S.A. pageant, to be held in March in Los Angeles, has recently weathered a wave of questionable publicity. The current Miss U.S.A., Tara Conner, has been treated for substance abuse, and Miss Nevada was deposed after a Web site published explicit photographs of her taken several years ago. Ms. Harder said this was something different. ''This isn't another scandal,'' she told The News. ''This is a baby; this is a life.''

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Pregnant Beauty Queen Quits

docs.abstract: Miss New Jersey Ashley Harder drops out of Miss USA pageant because she is pregnant, barring her from contest; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Morning sickness is a sign of a healthy pregnancy. THE FACTS -- It may be among the most unpleasant aspects of pregnancy, but can morning sickness also indicate a lower risk of miscarriage? A widespread belief holds that morning sickness can be a sort of blessing in disguise, or at least a favorable sign. Many dismiss this notion as folklore, but studies suggest that the truth is not so clear-cut.
docs.abstract: Women experiencing morning sickness generally have lower risk of miscarriage, but not necessarily healthier pregnancy than women not having morning sickness; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The parents of a 2-month-old Harlem boy who died on Saturday were charged with murder yesterday after they told detectives they had shaken and hit him to stop his crying, the police said.

headline.main: Parents Held in Baby’s Death After Saying They Shook Him
headline.print_headline: Parents Held in Baby’s Death After Saying They Shook Him

docs.snippet: The parents of a 2-month-old Harlem boy who died on Saturday were charged with murder yesterday after they told detectives they had shaken and hit him to stop his crying, the police said.
